data.title: Edward Jones analyst dissects Berkshire results, sees Abel restoring investor confidence
data.description:
Berkshire Hathaway's (BRK.A)(BRK.B) Q3 results beat expectations, according to Edward Jones analyst James Shanahan, helped by a sharp improvement in its insurance underwriting business and a solid contribution from aerospace parts maker Precision Castparts.

Shanahan highlighted the brokerage's recent rating upgrade of the sprawling conglomerate's stock following a period of sharp underperformance and backed CEO-elect Greg Abel to restore investor confidence over time.

The Omaha, Neb.-based giant earlier on Saturday posted a nearly 34% gain in operating earnings. Meanwhile, its cash pile swelled to record levels amid no share buybacks, approaching $390B.

"BRK now has over $380B in cash and short-term U.S. Treasury bills, which represents an increase of $48B year-to-date. Stock sales exceeded purchases by $6B during the quarter, marking the 12th consecutive quarter in which BRK was a net seller of stocks (cumulative net sales of $183B). Also, for the fifth consecutive quarter, BRK did not repurchase any of its own shares," Shanahan said in a research note. 

Last month, Berkshire (BRK.A)(BRK.B) finally tapped into its cash, announcing its largest acquisition since 2022 after agreeing to buy Occidental's (OXY) chemical business for $9.7B.

"BRK's $9.7B acquisition of OxyChem from Occidental Petroleum (OXY) is expected to close during the fourth quarter," Shanahan noted. 

This is the conglomerate's last quarterly report with top boss Warren Buffett at the helm. The famed 95-year-old businessman in May said he will be stepping down as CEO at the end of the year and will be replaced by his chosen successor, Greg Abel, who will also start writing annual letters in 2026.

Since the announcement, class A (BRK.A) and B (BRK.B) shares of Berkshire have slipped about -11.5% each, a stark contrast to the broader S&P 500's (SP500) +20.3% rise. The divergence in performance indicates that BRK stock has lost its "Buffett premium."   

"We recently upgraded BRK shares to a Buy from a Hold, following a period of sharp underperformance that followed the announcement of Warren Buffett's retirement as CEO at year-end. We believe that CEO-designate Greg Abel will restore investor confidence over time. In the near term, however, increased investment activity and/or share repurchases could be a catalyst for BRK shares," Edward Jones' Shanahan said.

data.title: Insider trades: Coca-Cola, Oracle, P&G among notable names this week
data.description:
Insider transactions were seen across companies, including Oracle (ORCL), Coca-Cola (KO) and Kinder Morgan (KMI), this week. The following is a list of transactions that occurred between October 27 and October 31.

  • Oracle’s (ORCL) Director Jeffrey Berg sold 49,365 shares at $283.02 apiece for a total value of $13.97M. Berg continues to hold 156,999 Oracle shares.
  • Procter & Gamble’s (PG) SVP and Chief Accounting Officer Matthew Janzaruk sold 725 shares for $149.57 each, totaling $108,438. He now holds 4272 shares in the company.
  • RTX’s (RTX) Director Tracy Atkinson disposed of 2,800 shares at $178.91 per share, worth $500,948. Her holdings have reduced to 4,080 shares.
  • Srinivasan Sivaram, CEO of QuantumScape (QS) CEO let go of a total of 120,000 shares across two transactions in the price range of $16.61 to $17.05, for a total value of $2.03M. Sivaram now owns 360,000 shares in the firm.
  • Corning’s (GLW) SVP of Finance and Corporate Controller Stefan Becker diluted his holding in the company by selling 12,100 shares for $91.28 each, for a total worth of $1.10M. He now holds 5,049 shares. Meanwhile, the company’s retired President Eric Musser divested 100,000 shares for $90.17 apiece, worth $9.02M. Musser continues to hold 44,926 shares.
  • On the buy side, Coca-Cola’s (KO) Director Max Levchin purchased a total of 14,267 shares across two transactions for a combined value of $998,677.
  • Kinder Morgan’s (KMI) Executive Chairman Richard Kinder acquired 1M shares at $25.96 each, totaling $25.96M. He now holds about 258M shares of the company.

data.title: Trump’s Tariffs: Key announcements from October
data.description:
Ever since U.S. President Donald Trump has taken office, one of the many things that has constantly dominated headlines was his tariff policy.

Although Trump had imposed tariffs during his first term, his latest actions roiled markets, disrupted diplomatic ties, and shook industries. The back-and-forth tariff stance and retaliatory measures have put investors on shaky ground.

Click here to see the tariff timeline from January this year. Here are the key developments that took place in October:

Oct 1, 2025: Taiwan - home to the biggest contract chipmaker, TSMC - said that it will not agree to produce 50% of its semiconductors in the U.S.

Oct 7, 2025: President Trump announced a new 25% tariff on all medium and heavy-duty trucks imported into the U.S., effective November 1, 2025.

"Beginning November 1st, 2025, all Medium and Heavy Duty Trucks coming into the United States from other Countries will be Tariffed at the Rate of 25%. Thank you for your attention to this matter!" Trump wrote on his Truth Social account.

Oct 9, 2025: According to a report from The Wall Street Journal, the Trump administration isn't planning to impose tariffs on generic drug imports, although the move isn't final and could change in the coming week.

Oct 10, 2025: President Trump said the U.S. will impose a tariff of 100% on China. He would also impose export controls on any and all critical software on November 1.

Trump also said he now sees "no reason" to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping, in response to what he called the nation's "hostile" export controls on rare earths.

The tariff warning from Trump triggered more than $19B in crypto liquidations from over 1.6M traders on Oct 10.

Oct 12, 2025: China pushed back against President Trump’s threat to impose 100% tariffs on Chinese goods, warning that it “will not back down” in the face of escalating trade pressure. However, the President sought to dial down tensions with Beijing, saying “it will all be fine” with China and that the U.S. “wants to help China, not hurt it.”

Oct 13, 2025: President Trump threatened to impose export controls on Boeing (BA) aircraft parts destined for China in direct response to announced restrictions on rare earth mineral exports, Reuters reported.

Oct 14, 2025: The U.S. and China said they will begin charging new port fees on each other’s vessels. Also new US tariffs came into effect on imported timber, kitchen cabinets, and upholstered furniture, much of which comes from China.

According to a report from The Straits Times, the implementation of the U.S. 100% tariff on Singapore's pharmaceutical exports—originally scheduled to take effect October 1, 2025—has been delayed to allow pharmaceutical companies time to negotiate possible exemptions with the U.S. administration.

Oct 15, 2025: President Trump threatened to escalate the trade war with China, suggesting his administration might halt business with the country over cooking oil imports. Trump said this month he hopes to discuss soybeans with his Chinese counterpart.

Trump also threatened trade penalties, including tariffs, against Spain due to its refusal to increase its NATO defense spending to 5% of GDP.

Oct 20, 2025: President Trump has once again claimed that Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi pledged to stop buying Russian oil, warning that "massive" tariffs would continue if the purchases didn't stop.

Oct 23, 2025: The Trump administration is considering new restrictions on exports to China involving products made with U.S. software, Reuters reported, citing a U.S. official and three people briefed by U.S. authorities.

Meanwhile, China said that Vice Premier He Lifeng will meet with U.S. officials in Kuala Lumpur from October 24 to 27 for a new round of trade negotiations.

Oct 25, 2025: President Trump said he would be increasing the tariff rate on Canadian goods by another 10% after the North American nation drew his ire by airing an ad featuring former President Ronald Reagan talking negatively about tariffs.

Oct 26, 2025: President Trump unveiled a series of trade pacts across Asia, seeking to secure critical mineral access and new markets for American farm exports before summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping, according to news reports. He offered tariff exemptions to Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam and Malaysia in exchange for lower barriers on American goods.

The U.S. and China also signalled progress in trade talks as soybean purchases resume.

Oct 27, 2025: Trump said he won’t resume Canada trade talks ‘for a while’ amid Reagan ad row.

Oct 28, 2025: U.S. and Japan have signed a deal to strengthen collaboration on critical minerals. Furthermore, Japanese exports to the U.S. will now face 15% tariffs.

Oct 30, 2025:  President Trump announced a one-year agreement with China covering rare earths and critical minerals, while also halving fentanyl-related tariffs on Beijing (from 20% to 10%), effective immediately, following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea.

Here are some exchange-traded funds that track the benchmark S&P 500 index (SP500): (NYSEARCA:SPY), (NYSEARCA:VOO), (NYSEARCA:IVV), (NYSEARCA:RSP), (NYSEARCA:SSO), (NYSEARCA:UPRO), (NYSEARCA:SH), (NYSEARCA:SDS), and (NYSEARCA:SPXU).

ETFs: (NYSEARCA:EWG), (NYSE:GF), (NYSEARCA:EWI), (NYSEARCA:EWQ), (NASDAQ:FGM), (NASDAQ:DAX), (NYSEARCA:FLGR), (NYSEARCA:FXB), (NYSEARCA:EWU), (NASDAQ:FKU), (BATS:EWUS), (NYSEARCA:FLGB), (NYSEARCA:GREK)

Dear readers: We recognize that politics often intersects with the financial news of the day, so we invite you to click here to join the separate political discussion.

data.title: Notable analyst calls this week: Meta, Boeing and Comcast among top picks
data.description:
The S&P 500 (SP500) closed in the green on Friday, after investors saw a week full of earnings report from big tech firms including Meta, Apple, Alphabet and Amazon.

For the week, Nasdaq (COMP:IND) and Dow (DJI) fell marginally. Wall Street had a slew of upgrades and downgrades from analysts. Here are some of the major calls for the week:

Meta grabs limelight following Q3 results

Oppenheimer downgraded Meta’s (META) rating to Perform from Outperform and removed its price target following Q3 results, and said risk/reward is "properly reflected" after the stock's plunge.

The research firm said the company's significant investment in its AI superintelligence unit, despite the unknown revenue opportunity, mirrors 2021/2022 Metaverse spending.

Citigroup maintained its Buy rating but lowered PT to $850 from $915, while acknowledging that the magnitude of investments is greater than what most expected.

Piper Sandler called the results "very impressive" and said the pressure on shares from the expense commentary for 2026 is a buying opportunity.

Bernstein also lowered PT by $30 to $870 on Meta, while BofA cut it by $90 to $810.

Fiserv in focus after Wall Street downgrades to Hold

Fiserv (FI) was in focus after Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and BTIG cut their recommendation on the stock to Hold-equivalent after the payment technology company's third quarter earnings release.

BTIG analysts Andrew Harte and Thomas Smith think "FI has lost its prestigious "high quality" label, as its 39-year streak of double-digit EPS growth been abruptly upended and numbers indicate the business is not a clear share-taker in either segment."

Morgan Stanley analyst ames Faucette downgraded the stock to Equal-weight from Overweight and slashed PT to $81 from $179.

"The work will take time, and so will rebuilding investor confidence," added Faucette.

Boeing downgraded on slower cash flow recovery

Boeing (BA) was downgraded to Hold from Buy by Deutsche Bank, as the analysts pointed to weaker free cash flow projections through 2027 and limited upside relative to current valuation.

Analysts led by Scott Deuschle said the downgrade reflects a recalibration of Boeing’s 2025-28 outlook, with free cash flow forecasts reduced to $2.1 billion for 2026, $6.0 billion for 2027 and $11.2 billion for 2028.

While Deuschle praised Boeing’s (BA) leadership for “making the right operational decisions,” particularly in the 737 and 787 programs, he cautioned that “the financial picture remains constrained by the burdens of the past.”

Comcast downgraded after third-quarter results

KeyBanc lowered rating on Comcast (CMCSA) to Sector weight from Overweight, citing a lack of catalysts following the company's third-quarter results.

KeyBanc pointed out that Comcast's broadband penetration rate has fallen for 14 consecutive quarters, and hence they need to see signs of stabilization before becoming more constructive on the company.

"Competitive concerns in broadband are likely to continue for the foreseeable future as telecom providers ramp fiber and FWA offerings over the next several years, where it's uncertain if and when Comcast will return to broadband subscriber growth," the brokerage said. KeyBanc currently does not have a price target for CMCSA.

Warner Bros. Discovery upgraded on potential bidding war

Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) was upgraded to Buy from Hold at Argus on the potential for a bidding war. The upgrade comes after Warner Bros. announced last Monday that it was undertaking a strategic review of its assets.

"While there is no assurance a deal will actually get done, we like that WBD management has opened up the process to look at a range of alternatives to maximize the shareholder value of the WBD assets," said Argus analyst Joseph Bonner. He has a price target of $27 for the stock.

RBC upgraded Honeywell International (HON) to Outperform from Sector Perform, arguing that the U.S. industrial conglomerate is entering a “catalyst-rich phase” ahead of its planned breakup in the second half of 2026.

Jefferies and Wolfe Research both upgraded Edwards Lifesciences (EW) with Jefferies citing recent strong data for the SAPIEN M3 transcatheter mitral valve replacement (TMVR) and EVOQUE transcatheter tricuspid valve replacement (TTVR) systems, and Wolfe saying that risks it saw with the company are now unlikely to lead to negative results in the short term.

data.title: Argentine banks dominate week's financials movers on Milei's election victory
data.description:
Argentine bank stocks led this week's financials movers with significant gains after President Javier Milei's ruling party scored a midterm victory, fueling broad investor optimism over his pro-market reforms. In the U.S., earnings season ramped up, helping shape some of the other movers.

With a stronger peso on the back of the election victory, Grupo Financiero Galicia (GGAL) soared 67% in the week ended Oct. 31, making it the biggest winner among financials (with market cap over $2B).

From there, BBVA Argentina (BBAR) jumped 64% and Banco Macro (BMA) gapped up 57%;

Brighthouse Financial (BHF) popped 20% after a report that Aquarian Holdings was in advanced talks to acquire the U.S. life insurer; and

Lemonade (LMND) advanced 15%. 

For the five biggest losers, Bancorp (TBBK) took the lead, dropping 17%, following worse-than-expected Q3 earnings;

Technology-enabled payments company Sezzle (SEZL) retreated 15%;

Bitcoin miner Bitfarms (BITF) slid 14%;

Crypto investment firm Galaxy Digital (GLXY), which during the week priced a $1.15B exchangeable senior notes offering, shed 12%; and

Investment bank PJT Partners (PJT) fell 11.9%.

data.title: Berkshire Hathaway Q3 profit jumps 34%, cash pile swells to record ~$382B amid no buybacks
data.description:
Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B) on Saturday posted a nearly 34% gain in operating profit, helped by a strong performance in its insurance underwriting business. Meanwhile, the sprawling conglomerate's cash pile swelled to record levels amid no share buybacks, approaching $390B.

This is the Omaha, Neb.-based giant's last quarterly report with famed top boss Warren Buffett at the helm. The 95-year-old businessman will be stepping down as CEO at the end of the year and will be replaced by his chosen successor, Greg Abel, who will also start writing annual letters in 2026.          

Berkshire's (BRK.A)(BRK.B) Q3 operating earnings jumped 33.6% Y/Y to $13.49B. The company returned to quarterly operating earnings growth after posting back-to-back declines in Q2 and Q1. See the chart below: 

Overall Q3 net earnings attributable to shareholders rose 17.3% Y/Y to $30.80B.            

The company's cash pile increased to a whopping $381.67B as of September 30, 2025, from $344.09B as of June 30, 2025.

The new cash pile surpassed the previous record of $347.68B at the end of Q1, as BRK again held back from any share repurchases. Class A (BRK.A) and B (BRK.B) shares of the conglomerate have underperformed the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) this year, indicating that the stock has lost its "Buffett premium."

Last month, Berkshire (BRK.A)(BRK.B) announced its biggest acquisition since 2022, agreeing to buy Occidental's (OXY) chemical business for $9.7B.       

See below for a breakdown of the company's Q3 earnings performance by segment:

Berkshire's (BRK.A)(BRK.B) insurance underwriting segment shone in Q3, with operating earnings more than tripling Y/Y to $2.37B.

"The comparative earnings increase in the third quarter was primarily attributable to lower incurred losses from current year significant catastrophe events and from prior accident years’ claims, as well as the impact of accruals in the third quarter of 2024 in connection with a bankruptcy settlement," the company said. 

Conversely, after-tax earnings from the conglomerate's insurance investment income business slipped 13.2% Y/Y to $3.18B, primarily due to lower interest rates and the impact of capital distributions. 

Looking at Berkshire's (BRK.A)(BRK.B) investment returns, most of which are unrealized, the company logged gains of $17.31B in Q3, compared to gains of $16.16B a year ago.

Turning to the performance of the conglomerate's railroad business, quarterly after-tax earnings at BNSF climbed 4.8% Y/Y to $1.45B.

BNSF operates one of the largest railroad systems in North America, with over 32.5K route miles of track in 28 states. Its car/unit volumes gained 0.8% in Q3, driven by a jump in freight volume of consumer products.

Moving to Berkshire Hathaway Energy, after-tax earnings fell 8.6% Y/Y to $1.49B in Q3, reflecting lower earnings in U.S. utilities and natural gas pipelines.

Finally, quarterly after-tax earnings from Berkshire's (BRK.A)(BRK.B) manufacturing, service, and retailing businesses improved 8.2% Y/Y to $3.62B.

data.title: Berkshire Hathaway Q3 operating earnings +33.6% Y/Y, cash pile hits record $381.67B
data.description:
• Berkshire Hathaway press release (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B): Q3 operating earnings of $13.49B (+33.6% Y/Y).
  • Q3 total revenue of $94.97B (+2.1% Y/Y).
  • Net earnings per average equivalent Class A share of $21,413.
  • Net earnings per average equivalent Class B share of $14.28.
  • Cash, cash equivalents, and short-term securities of $381.67B.
  • SEC filing.

data.title: Tech giants brace to spend billions more in CapEx as AI race heats up
data.description:
Tech giants Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Meta Platforms (META) are spending billions of dollars to build AI infrastructure, and some have even raised their expectations for the next year as the AI race heats up.

Meta (META)

The Facebook parent expects full year 2025 total expenses to be in the range of $116B to $118B, revised from its prior outlook of $114B to $118B, reflecting a growth rate of 22% to 24% year-over-year. The company expects 2025 capital expenditures, including principal payments on finance leases, to be in the range of $70B to $72B, increased from its prior outlook of $66B to $72B.

Meta said it will "spend aggressively" next year, warning its capital expenditures will be "notably larger" in 2026 and total expenses will grow at a "significantly faster percentage rate."

"While our progress on AI models and products will position us to capitalize on new revenue opportunities in the years to come. A central requirement to realizing these opportunities is infrastructure capacity," said CFO Susan Li on the company's third quarter earnings call.

Li added that the company is still working through its capacity plans for next year, but it expects to invest aggressively to meet these needs, both by building its own infrastructure and contracting with third-party cloud providers.

"We anticipate this will provide further upward pressure on our CapEx and expense plans next year. As a result, our current expectation is that CapEx dollar growth will be notably larger in 2026 than 2025. We also anticipate total expenses will grow at a significantly faster percentage rate than 2025, with growth primarily driven by infrastructure costs, including incremental cloud expenses and depreciation," Li noted.

The Instagram and WhatsApp owner is planning to raise up to $30B through bond offerings.

Alphabet (GOOG) (GOOGL)

Alphabet raised its forecast for capital expenditure for 2025 and 2026.

"We're continuing to invest aggressively due to the demand we're experiencing from Cloud customers as well as the growth opportunities we see across the company. We now expect CapEx to be in the range of $91 billion to $93 billion in 2025, up from our previous estimate of $85 billion," said Alphabet's Senior Vice President and CFO Anat Ashkenazi during the third quarter earnings call.

Google had previously indicated $22.4B in capex for the third quarter — it came in at just under $24B — and analysts had expected full-year capex would come in at just over $84B.

"Looking out to 2026, we expect a significant increase in CapEx," said Ashkenazi adding that the company will provide more detail on its fourth quarter earnings call.

Ashkenazi noted that in terms of expenses, as previously mentioned, the "significant increase in our investments in technical infrastructure will continue to put pressure on the P&L" in the form of higher depreciation expenses and related data center operations costs such as energy.

Microsoft (MSFT)

The software giant expects to spend more in fiscal 2026 to grow its business than it previously forecast.

"With accelerating demand and a growing RPO [remaining performance obligation] balance, we're increasing our spend on GPUs and CPUs. Therefore, total spend will increase sequentially, and we now expect the FY '26 growth rate to be higher than FY '25," said Amy Hood, executive vice president and CFO, on the company's first quarter fiscal 2026 earnings call.

Hood noted that capital expenditures were $34.9B in the first quarter, driven by growing demand for our Cloud and AI offerings. About half of the spend was on short-lived assets, mainly GPUs and CPUs, to support increasing Azure platform demand, growing first-party apps at AI solutions, accelerating research and development, or R&D, by product teams, and continued replacement for end-of-life server and networking equipment, according to Hood.

"The remaining spend was for long-lived assets that will support monetization for the next 15 years and beyond, including $11.1 billion of finance leases that are primarily for large data center sites. And cash paid for PP&E was $19.4 billion," Hood added.

Amazon (AMZN)

Amazon said its cash CapEx was $34.2B in the third quarter and the company has spent $89.9B so far this year. The e-commerce giant noted that it will continue to make significant investments, especially in AI.

"This primarily relates to AWS [Amazon Web Services] as we invest to support demand for our AI and core services and in custom silicon, like Trainium as well as tech infrastructure to support our North America and international segments. We'll continue to make significant investments, especially in AI, as we believe it to be a massive opportunity with the potential for strong returns on invested capital over the long term," said Brian Olsavsky, Amazon's senior vice president and CFO on the company's third quarter earnings call.

Apple (AAPL)

The iPhone maker did not disclose the exact amount for capital expenditure but noted that the company is expecting increases in its CapEx spending related to AI.

In a query related to big tech companies increasing their CapEx in advance of AI demand, Kevan Parekh, Apple (AAPL) senior vice president and CFO, said on the company's fourth quarter earnings call that "we are expecting increases in our CapEx spending related to AI investments. For example, as I mentioned earlier, we did end up having investments this year to build out our Private Cloud Compute environment. And we do believe this hybrid model has served us very well, and we continue to want to leverage it. And so I don't see us moving away from this hybrid model where we leverage both first-party capacity as well as leverage third-party capacity."

Parekh added that the company will continue to want to build out Private Cloud Compute, as it has more usage there over time. "But I think, in general, we want to continue to have this hybrid model," Parekh noted.

data.title: Cavco signals balanced market and expands retail footprint following American Homestar acquisition
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Cavco Industries, Inc. (CVCO) Q2 2026

Management View

  • CEO William Boor opened the call by highlighting "focused execution across our operations that led to the strong overall results we're reviewing today." He noted revenue increased 9.7% year-over-year and was flat sequentially, while operating profit rose about 27% from last year's Q2 and 3% over last quarter.
  • Boor emphasized "notable regional differences," with the Northern U.S. seeing double-digit shipment growth and the Southeast region experiencing a slowdown, as shipments in the area from the Carolinas and Tennessee to Louisiana were down about 4% year-to-date and down 10% in July and August compared to last year.
  • Production rates were adjusted: "we did need to slow our Southeast production in Q2 and the plants reacted well," explained Boor, citing extended downtime and rate reductions in the Southeast, while other regions maintained elevated production rates.
  • On backlogs, Boor stated "we remained at about 5 to 7 weeks. Unit backlog was up slightly quarter-to-quarter."
  • Boor highlighted the financial services segment: "operating profit is up $14 million from a loss last year to an $8 million profit this year. This has been driven by our insurance business."
  • The American Homestar acquisition closed after Q2 ended. Boor said, "integration is moving quickly and very well," and the combined company "is off to a great start."
  • Boor underscored capital allocation: "we continued investing in our existing plants. We closed on the American Homestar acquisition immediately after the quarter using cash on hand, and we were able to repurchase $36 million of our common shares."
  • CFO Allison Aden reported, "Net revenue for the second fiscal quarter of 2026 was $556.5 million, up $49 million or 9.7% from $507.5 million in the prior year quarter."

Outlook

  • Management described the market as "in balance with manufacturer production," with Boor stating "there are scenarios that it strengthens and others that it weakens from here. We're comfortable operating in this environment because we've demonstrated the ability to closely monitor and adjust."
  • The company remains focused on monitoring regional variations, especially in the Southeast, and stands ready to adjust production as needed to maintain backlogs.

Financial Results

  • Factory-built housing segment net revenue was $535.1 million, up $48.8 million or 10% from $486.3 million in the prior year quarter, driven by a 5.4% increase in homes sold and a 4.4% rise in average revenue per home sold.
  • Financial services segment net revenue was $21.4 million, up $0.3 million or 1.4% from the prior year quarter.
  • Consolidated gross profit as a percentage of revenue was 24.2%, up 130 basis points from 22.9% last year.
  • Selling, general and administrative expenses were $72.2 million or 13% of net revenue, compared to $67 million or 13.2% last year, with the increase due to higher incentive compensation and deal costs from the American Homestar acquisition.
  • Interest income was $5 million, down from $5.7 million last year.
  • Pretax profit was $67.3 million, up $12.3 million or 22.4% from $55 million in the prior year period.
  • Net income was $52.4 million and diluted earnings per share was $6.55 per share versus $5.28 per share last year.
  • The company repurchased just over $36 million of common shares and closed the American Homestar acquisition using cash on hand.

Q&A

  • Dan Moore, CJS Securities, Inc.: Asked about order trends and production rates in Q3. Boor responded that "our wholesale orders were down just a little bit in the quarter" and production rates remain relatively steady, with adjustments localized by region.
  • Moore inquired about Texas market dynamics. Boor said, "we had a really, really good quarter in retail" and "the market is there. Our retail guys are doing a great job."
  • Moore asked about gross margin expectations and tariff impacts. Aden said, "the impact of tariffs in Q2 was approximately $2 million," and future impacts will depend on commodity prices and market conditions.
  • Greg Palm, Craig-Hallum: Asked about Cavco's ability to outgrow the industry. Boor attributed this to digital marketing, rebranding, and a strengthened national sales team.
  • Palm inquired about the mix of homes sold through company-owned retail. Mark Fusler said, "this quarter, we're about 22.9% that were sold through our retail channel."
  • Jay McCanless, Wedbush: Asked about multi-section home trends. Boor noted an uptick but said "I'm not sure that we've really got a theory that it's a trend."
  • Jesse Lederman, Zelman & Associates: Asked about financial services margin improvements. Boor emphasized that "well over 50% of the improvement is due to the changes we've made" in underwriting and claims management.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on regional differences, production adjustments, margins, and the integration of American Homestar. Their tone was neutral to slightly positive, with direct questions about risks and future impacts.
  • Management's tone during prepared remarks was confident, highlighting operational flexibility and strong results. During Q&A, responses were detailed and balanced, acknowledging uncertainties but expressing comfort with current market positioning. Boor used phrases such as "we're comfortable operating in this environment" and "not intending to be evasive, it's more that we're just seeing all conditions across the country."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both management and analysts maintained a steady tone, with slightly increased focus on cost pressures and regional shipment dynamics.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Revenue was effectively flat sequentially, while operating profit increased 3% over last quarter.
  • The previous quarter saw a 16.6% sequential revenue increase, while this quarter was flat due to seasonal trends and regional variation.
  • There is a continued focus on regional shipment performance, especially as the Southeast lagged while the Northern regions outperformed.
  • Management reiterated confidence in the company’s ability to adjust production as needed and highlighted the completed American Homestar acquisition, which was pending in the prior quarter.
  • Analysts maintained a similar focus on regional performance, pricing, and cost pressures, but questioned more deeply on integration and product mix following the acquisition.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited "significant regional differences" in shipment trends, with the Southeast slowing while other regions grew.
  • Tariff increases, particularly on Canadian lumber, are expected to impact costs. Aden explained, "the Canadian lumber countervailing duties have been increased from their long-term 14.5% to 35%," with an additional 10% tariff announced.
  • Management is monitoring the ability to pass through increased costs, noting that "our ability to pass these costs through pricing will be very dependent upon local market conditions."
  • The impact of regulatory changes and the ongoing integration of the American Homestar acquisition were also mentioned as areas to watch.

Final Takeaway

Cavco Industries delivered solid financial results in Q2 2026 with steady revenue, improved profitability, and notable strength in its financial services business. The company navigated regional shipment differences by actively managing production rates and maintained healthy backlogs. The successful closing and integration of the American Homestar acquisition expands Cavco's retail presence, positioning the company for future growth. Cost pressures from tariffs and regional shipment uncertainty remain, but management emphasized operational agility and a balanced capital allocation strategy as key to sustaining performance going forward.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Exxon and Chevron keep boosting production despite weak oil price outlook
data.description:
Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), the two biggest U.S. oil giants, increased their production during Q3 despite forecasts for a global supply glut and weakening oil prices.

The output hikes threaten to further exacerbate the weakening oil price environment heading into 2026, with the U.S. WTI benchmark hovering near the $60/bbl threshold that companies generally need to maintain profitability - but the biggest producers have more scale to push ahead through lower prices.

Rising output has helped soften the impact of a ~$10/bbl drop in spot prices over the past 12 months.

Exxon (XOM) said in its Q3 earnings report that it achieved another production record of nearly 1.7 million boe/day in the Permian Basin and exceeded 700,000 bbl/day at its operations in Guyana, as the company's overall production rose to 4.8 million bbl/day from 4.6 million bbl/day in Q2.

"We set yet another production record," Exxon (XOM) Chairman and CEO Darren Woods said on Friday's earnings conference call. "Our Permian production continues to grow well into the next decade. It clearly differentiates us from our competitors, who are talking about reduced investments, peak production, or a shift to harvest mode."

Exxon's (XOM) execution success was tempered by another increase in debt levels, indicating the company is not covering its dividend and buyback with free cash flow, HSBC analyst Kim Fustier said in a note.

Chevron (CVX) said in its Q3 results that output reached a record 4.1 million bbl/day of oil, up 21% Y/Y, including the integration of Hess, which added nearly a half-million bbl/day to production, but another 227 million bbl/day came from an expansion of its operations at the company's U.S. and Kazakhstan operations.

Chevron's (CVX) Permian production continues to grow, producing 60,000 bbl/day above the company’s 1 million bbl/day plateau level.

The U.S. Energy Information Administration has forecast the price of Brent crude oil will average $62/bbl in Q4 and drop further to $52/bbl in FY 2026.

Crude oil futures ticked higher Friday ahead of the OPEC+ weekend meeting that is expected to lead to another production increase in December, with most analysts believing the group will choose a "cautious" output hike of 137,000 bbl/day, in line with increases approved for October and November.

Reports that the Trump administration is considering strikes against military targets in Venezuela gave oil prices a modest lift; President Trump issued a denial on social media.

This week, front-month Nymex crude for December delivery (CL1:COM) closed -0.8% to $60.98/bbl, and front-month Brent December crude (CO1:COM) ended -1.3% to $65.07/bbl; on Friday, the benchmarks rose 0.7% and 0.1%, respectively.

U.S. natural gas futures rose for a third straight session, +3.2% this week to $4.124/MMBtu, as the market turns its focus to coming winter weather and higher demand; on Friday, the front-month Nymex December contract (NG1:COM) gained 4.2%.

ETFs: (USO), (BNO), (UCO), (SCO), (USL), (DBO), (DRIP), (GUSH), (USOI), (UNG), (BOIL), (KOLD), (UNL), (FCG), (XLE)

Energy stocks, as represented by the Energy Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLE), finished the week roughly flat.

Top 20 gainers in energy and natural resources in the past 5 days: Empresa Distribuidora y Comercializadora Norte Sociedad Anónima (EDN) +71.9%, Central Puerto (CEPU) +64.6%, Propetro Holding (PUMP) +64.5%, Transportadora de Gas del Sur (TGS) +38.5%, Canadian Solar (CSIQ) +38.4%, Pampa Energia (PAM) +37%, YPF (YPF) +35.2%, Profrac Holding (ACDC) +26.9%, Daqo New Energy (DQ) +25.4%, Vista Energy (VIST) +21%, Uranium Royalty (UROY) +20.6%, Bloom Energy (BE) +19.7%, Geopark (GPRK) +19%, Nuscale Power (SMR) +18.9%, Atlas Energy Solutions (AESI) +17.8%, JinkoSolar (JKS) +16.5%, Cameco (CCJ) +16%, OMS Energy Technologies (OMSE) +16%, North European Oil Royalty Trust (NRT) +14%, Cactus (WHD) +13.5%.

Top 10 decliners in energy and natural resources in the past 5 days: Flux Power (FLUX) -61.4%, VivoPower International (VVPR) -40%, U.S. Antimony (UAMY) -32.8%, Itron (ITRI) -26.2%, Trilogy Metals (TMQ) -25.7%, Sable Offshore (SOC) -21.7%, Empire Petroleum (EP) -21.4%, NexMetals Mining (NEXM) -20.9%, Tigo Energy (TYGO) -18.3%, Lithium Americas (LAC) -18.1%.

Source: Barchart.com
